render.tex: \title{Matrix Multiplication} \\ %text How to multiply with matrices %

reason.tex: %text For two matrices $A$ and $B$ to be multiplied with each other, the number of columns in $A$ needs to equal the number of rows in $B$. % \begin{align} A_{m\times n}\times B_{n\times o}=C_{m\times o} \end{align} \\ \textit{($M_{p\times q}$ - a matrix $M$ with $p$ rows and $q$ columns)}\\ %text The product matrix $C$ above would have as many rows as $A$ and as many columns as $B$. Here is an actual example, % \begin{align} \left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & 3\end{array}\right]\times\left[\begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 5 \\ 6 \end{array}\right] =&[(1\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 6)] \\ =&[4+10+18]=[32] \end{align} \\ %text Here is another example, % \begin{align} &\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{array}\right]\times \left[\begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \\ e & f \end{array}\right]\\ =&\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1a+2c+3e & 1b+2d+3f \\ 4a+5c+6e & 4b+5d+6f \\ 7a+8c+9e & 7b+8d+9f \end{array}\right] \end{align}\\ %text Any generic element $p_{ij}$ in the product matrix of $A_{m\times n}$ and $B_{n\times o}$ is given by, % \begin{align} p_{ij}&=\sum_{k=1}^na_{ik}\times b_{kj} \end{align} \\ %text Multiplying a matrix with a scalar $k$ is much simpler. Each element of the matrix gets multiplied by $k$. % \begin{align} &kA_{m\times n}=k\times[a_{ij}]_{m\times n}=[k(a_{ij})]_{m\times n} \\ & k\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \\ e & f \end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{cc} ka & kb \\ kc & kd \\ ke & kf \end{array}\right] \end{align}
